Add more interesting stories and anecdotes to this list below that are different: Certainly! Here are some interesting stories and anecdotes about how different alcoholic spirits brought people together in history to do interesting things:

Rum and pirates: Rum was a favorite drink of pirates in the 17th and 18th centuries. It was often used as a form of payment and was a key ingredient in popular pirate cocktails such as the grog. Pirates would gather together to share a bottle of rum and plan their next raid or adventure.

Vodka and the Cold War: During the Cold War, vodka played a significant role in the diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and the United States. In 1959, Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev visited the United States and was famously given a tour of an Iowa farm, where he was served vodka and given a pair of cowboy boots. This helped to ease tensions between the two countries and paved the way for future diplomatic talks.

Absinthe and the Bohemian lifestyle: Absinthe was a popular drink among the bohemian artists and writers of 19th-century Paris. It was often enjoyed during late-night conversations and debates, and was believed to stimulate creativity and inspire artistic expression.

Sake and the Japanese tea ceremony: In Japan, sake has been a key component of the traditional tea ceremony for centuries. Sake is served to guests during the ceremony, which emphasizes the importance of harmony, respect, and tranquility.

Tequila and the Mexican Revolution: During the Mexican Revolution, tequila was used as a form of currency and was often given to soldiers as a reward for their bravery. Today, tequila is still an important part of Mexican culture and is often enjoyed during celebrations and social gatherings.

Whiskey and the American frontier: Whiskey was a popular drink among pioneers and settlers in the American West. It was often used as a form of medicine, as well as a way to celebrate milestones such as the completion of a successful harvest or the birth of a child.

Cognac and French royalty: Cognac has been a favorite drink of French royalty for centuries. In the 19th century, Napoleon Bonaparte famously requested a glass of cognac before his execution, and King George IV of England was known to have a personal cellar of over 10,000 bottles of the spirit.

Mezcal and Mexican traditions: Mezcal has long been an important part of Mexican traditions and celebrations. In some indigenous communities, mezcal is believed to have healing properties and is used in spiritual rituals and ceremonies.

Baijiu and Chinese culture: Baijiu is an important part of Chinese culture and is often served during business meetings and banquets. It is also a key component of traditional Chinese medicine and is believed to have medicinal properties.

Gin and British colonialism: Gin played a significant role in British colonialism, as it was used to mask the taste of quinine in tonic water, which was used to prevent malaria in British colonizers. This led to the creation of the popular cocktail known as the gin and tonic.

These are just a few examples of the interesting stories and anecdotes about how different alcoholic spirits brought people together in history to do interesting things. From pirates to diplomats to artists, alcohol has played a significant role in shaping human culture and history.

Case Study 1: The Young Athlete

John is a 20-year-old college student who has been an avid athlete since high school. He plays basketball, football, and runs regularly. About six months ago, he began experiencing lower back pain after a particularly grueling basketball game. Initially, John assumed it was just muscle soreness, but as the pain persisted, he became concerned.

John's pain is located in the lower back, just above the hips, and is accompanied by a dull ache that intensifies when he sits or stands for long periods. He has tried over-the-counter pain relievers, rest, and stretching, but nothing seems to alleviate the pain. He has even tried using a back brace, but it doesn't seem to make much of a difference.

After some initial tests, John's doctor diagnosed him with a lumbar strain, which is a common injury among athletes. John was advised to take a break from his sports activities, and his doctor recommended physical therapy to help alleviate his symptoms. John began working with a physical therapist to develop an exercise program that would help him strengthen his back muscles and improve his posture. The therapist also worked with John to address any underlying stress or anxiety that may have been contributing to his pain.

Through his physical therapy sessions, John learned that his pain was likely a combination of physical and emotional factors. His intense sports schedule, coupled with the stress of school and work, had caused his muscles to become tense and his body to become less resilient to injury. By learning how to manage his stress levels and maintain proper posture, John was able to significantly reduce his pain and return to his active lifestyle.

This case highlights the importance of a holistic approach to treating back pain. While physical therapy and exercise are crucial components of treatment, addressing the underlying emotional factors that contribute to pain can also play a significant role in recovery. By taking a comprehensive approach, patients can not only alleviate their pain but also improve their overall physical and emotional well-being.

Certainly! Here are some additions based on the suggestions:

Case Study: Duolingo
--------------------

Duolingo, a popular language learning platform, is an excellent example of a company that has successfully implemented a crowd-sourced approach to data collection. Although not a strict pay-to-play model, Duolingo leverages user-generated content for translating web content and creating new learning materials. As users practice and improve their language skills, they contribute to the platform's translation services. This approach benefits both the users, who receive a free language learning experience, and the platform, which obtains valuable translation data to improve its services.

Overcoming Challenges: Best Practices
-------------------------------------

To address the challenges and potential pitfalls associated with the pay-to-play model, startups should consider the following best practices:

1. **Data quality**: Establish a robust data validation process, including automated checks and peer review, to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the contributed data.
2. **Intellectual property and privacy**: Clearly communicate your platform's terms of use, data handling policies, and any licensing arrangements to address intellectual property and privacy concerns. Obtain user consent and adhere to relevant data protection regulations.
3. **Scalability**: Plan for scalability from the outset, incorporating flexible infrastructure and resources that can grow with your user base.
4. **User retention**: Encourage user retention by continuously updating and expanding the AI's services, providing personalized recommendations, and fostering a community atmosphere through user forums or social features.
5. **Monetization**: Experiment with different monetization strategies, such as offering premium features or subscriptions, to find a sustainable balance between the points-based system and generating revenue.

Future Trends: The Evolution of Pay-to-Play Models
--------------------------------------------------

As AI technologies advance, the pay-to-play model is likely to evolve and find new applications across various industries. Some potential trends include:

1. **Personalized AI services**: As AI models become more sophisticated, they may be able to provide highly personalized services tailored to individual users, increasing the value of the pay-to-play model for users.
2. **Blockchain and decentralized systems**: The integration of blockchain technology or other decentralized systems can help address data privacy and intellectual property concerns while providing a secure, transparent platform for managing points and transactions.
3. **Collaborative AI development**: The pay-to-play model could facilitate collaborative AI development by allowing users to contribute not just data but also algorithms, machine learning models, or other AI components, creating a decentralized ecosystem of AI contributors.

Call-to-Action
--------------

Are you interested in exploring the potential of the pay-to-play model for your AI startup? Have you encountered any challenges or success stories related to this approach? Share your thoughts, experiences, and questions in the comments section below. Let's continue the conversation and learn from each other's experiences!

It may seem counterintuitive, but the probability that Tuan wins is actually less than 50%. This is because Tuan and Alex each select a card uniformly at random from their respective decks, so there is no inherent advantage for either TA.

To see why the probability is less than 50%, consider the following simpler problem: suppose we flip a fair coin twice, and we win if the second flip is heads. There are four possible outcomes: $HH$, $HT$, $TH$, and $TT$, each of which has probability $\frac{1}{4}$. However, we win only in the $HT$ and $TT$ cases, so the probability of winning is $\frac{2}{4}=\frac{1}{2}$, which is less than 50%.

Similarly, in this problem, there are $13\times 13=169$ possible outcomes, each with probability $\frac{1}{169}$. However, Tuan wins only if his card has a strictly higher rank than Alex's card, which happens in $\frac{1}{2}(13-1)\cdot 13=78$ of the 169 possible outcomes (the factor of $\frac{1}{2}$ is because Tuan's card could be any of the 13 ranks, and if Alex's card is of a lower rank, there is only one outcome where Tuan wins, but if Alex's card is of a higher rank, there are two outcomes where Tuan wins). Therefore, the probability that Tuan wins is $\frac{78}{169}\approx 0.461$, which is indeed less than 50%.

summarise these 3 projects: "Dissertation Goals and Project Summaries
Dissertation Goals and Project Summaries
 07:11, September 20 , 2022

Project 1
In Project 1, I programmed a simple projectile launching task to serve as a conceptual replication of an influential paradigm in the visuomotor skill learning literature. Several of the canonical empirical patterns are replicated, with the varied trained participants tending to perform better during testing in both experiments. A major issue with previous research in the cross-disciplinary “benefits of variability” literature is that many previous works do not adequately control for the similarity between training and testing conditions. Such issues arise when both from failures to consider the possibility of non-linear generalization, and from often the unquestioned assumption that participants are acquiring, and then generalizing from prototype or schema-based representations. I introduce a theoretically motivated method of explicitly quantifying the similarity between training experience and testing condition. The resulting similarity quantity can then be used to explicitly control for similarity (by adding it as a covariate to the statistical model). The effect of variability remains significant while controlling for similarity, which I argue is a more rigorous demonstration of the effect of variability on testing performance than what is typically provided with standard methods. I conclude by introducing an extended version of the model that assumes training variation influences the steepness of the generalization gradient. With this flexible similarity mechanism, the group-level effect of variability can then be accounted for within the similarity-based generalization framework.
Link to Project 1 page
Alternatively, click here to download pdf of the journal article corresponding to project 1.

Project 2
In Project 2, a modified version of the task from Project 1 is used in conjunction with a testing procedure that challenges participants to extrapolate well beyond their training experience. In line with previous research in the function learning literature, participants show evidence of successful extrapolation in our linear task environment. Surprisingly though, the constant training group outperforms the varied training group consistently across numerous variants of the task. Such a pattern is far from unheard of in the vast literature on training variability, and it is therefore remains a worthwhile challenge to evaluate the ability of similarity-based models to account for the observed effects. Additionally, the cognitive process models implemented for project 2 will go beyond the modelling efforts of the previous project in two respects. 1) Extensions that enable the model to produce predictions of participant responses, and 2) fitting and attempting to account for behavior in both training AND testing phases of the experiment.
Link to Project 2 page

Project 3
For the third and final project, I will take advantage of a large dataset from Lost In Migration, a popular online game resembling the classic Eriksen flanker task. Due to randomization of game trials, some users experience much more variability in the early phases of the game than others. Additionally, the dataset provided by Lumos labs includes data from users who experienced a ‘high variability’ version of the game before being switched to the standard version. I will assess the influence of both variability-via-randomization, and variability-via-manipulation, and once again evaluate the ability of similarity-based-generalization models to account for the observed patterns. While the key theoretical questions, and general modeling approach will remain the same as the first two projects, the Lost In Migration’s dataset will present the opportunity to examine the influence of variability in a much more graded fashion, and to assess the ecological validity of the phenomena.

1. Kadence and the Hero's Journey

Kadence is looking to use the Hero's Journey as a guiding framework to develop their music, image, and public persona. The goal is to build a behind-the-scenes structure that will allow Kadence to evolve in a believable way, eventually leading to an unbelievable transformation. Kadence wants to deepen their connection with their audience by providing content that resonates with them and allows for a magical relationship to form.

2. Influence on Music, Image, and Public Persona

The Hero's Journey will influence Kadence's music, image, and public persona by allowing them to plan and organize their ideas and actions in a way that benefits their overall image. Kadence wants to stay true to their authenticity while also crafting a detailed world of their own that will eventually become brand material.

3. Example of Hero's Journey Influence

As an example, at some point in the journey, Kadence may face an unknown force that requires them to take action. With the Hero's Journey in mind, they may decide to express this through a change in their appearance, such as coloring their hair in an unusual color. This change would be preceded by subtle hints and "easter eggs" that build up over time, allowing their audience to create their own theories and discussions about Kadence.

4. Focus on Specific Elements or Stages

Kadence wants to focus on the beginning of the Hero's Journey, specifically the transition from the "Ordinary World" to the next phase. They want to maintain a humble persona and use the attributes from the Hero's Journey to their advantage, even without extravagant resources.

5. Themes and Messages

The themes that Kadence wants to convey through their incorporation of the Hero's Journey are darkness, mystery, luxury, wisdom, and resilience. The message they want to convey is that anything is possible for those who believe. Kadence wants to show that this is true through their music, image, and public persona.

Below is the model I'm using, please read it and print out the total production function in terms of I, G, C and A. 

Capital accumulation:
$$ K\_{f,t+1} = I\_{f,t} + (1-\delta\_f)K\_{f,t} $$

Energy production:
Fossil:
$$ Q\_{f,t} = A\_{f,t} K\_{f,t}^{\alpha\_{kf}} E\_{f,t}^{\alpha\_{ef}} $$
Green:
$$ Q\_{g,t} = A\_{g,t} K\_{g,t}^{\alpha\_{kg}} E\_{g,t}^{\alpha\_{eg}} $$

Energy consumption:
$$ C\_{f,t} = \min(D\_{f,t}, Q\_{f,t}) $$

Demand for energy:
$$D\_{f,t} = \epsilon\_f \frac{P\_{f,t}}{P\_{r,t}} \frac{Y\_{r,t}}{P\_{f,t}+P\_{g,t}} $$

Energy investment:
$$ I\_{t} = I\_{f,t} + I\_{g,t} $$
Investment in fossil energy:
$$I\_{f,t} = \alpha\_f \frac{P\_{f,t}}{P\_{f,t}+P\_{g,t}} Y\_{r,t} - \delta\_{f,t-1} K\_{f,t-1}$$
Depreciation for fossil energy:
$$\delta\_{f,t} = \delta\_{f,t-1} + \gamma\_f K\_{f,t-1}$$

Green energy capital:
$$ K\_{g,t+1} = I\_{g,t} + (1-\delta\_g)K\_{g,t} $$
Depreciation for green energy:
$$\delta\_{g,t} = \delta\_{g,t-1} + \gamma\_g K\_{g,t-1}$$

Investment in green energy:
$$I\_{g,t} = \alpha\_g \frac{P\_{g,t}}{P\_{f,t}+P\_{g,t}} Y\_{r,t} - \delta\_{g,t-1} K\_{g,t-1}$$

Hidden variables for production:
$$A\_{f,t} = e^{\eta\_{f,t}}$$
$$A\_{g,t} = e^{\eta\_{g,t}}$$


Returns on labor:
$$ W\_{f,t} = (1-\alpha\_{f})\frac{\eta\_{f} K\_{f,t}^{\alpha\_{f}} L\_{f,t}^{\beta\_{f}}}{E\_{f,t}} $$
$$ W\_{g,t} = (1-\alpha\_{g})\frac{\eta\_{g} K\_{g,t}^{\alpha\_{g}} L\_{g,t}^{\beta\_{g}}}{E\_{g,t}} $$
$$ W\_{r,t} = (1-\alpha\_{r})\frac{Y\_{r,t}}{L\_{r,t}} $$

Total output and consumption:
$$ Y\_{r,t} = C\_{f,t} + C\_{g,t} + Y\_{r,t-1} $$
$$ C\_{r,t} = \frac{\gamma\_{t}}{\gamma\_{t}+1} Y\_{r,t} $$
$$ H\_{t} = \frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\frac{E\_{f,t}}{E\_{f,0}}\right)^{1-\theta}+\left(\frac{E\_{g,t}}{E\_{g,0}}\right)^{1-\theta}\right] $$


Fossil fuel energy capital:
$$ K\_{f,t+1} = I\_{f,t} + (1-\delta\_{f})K\_{f,t} $$


 in green energy:

$I\_{G,t} = \alpha\_G (K\_{G,t} - \delta\_{G,t-1})$

$K\_{G,t} = K\_{G,t-1} + I\_{G,t}$


Where:

$I\_{F,t}$: Investment in fossil energy at time $t$

$\alpha\_F$: Share of output invested in fossil energy

$K\_{F,t}$: Capital stock in fossil energy at time $t$

$\delta\_{F,t}$: Depreciation of capital stock in fossil energy at time $t$

$\gamma\_F$: Depreciation rate for fossil energy

$I\_{G,t}$: Investment in green energy at time $t$

$\alpha\_G$: Share of output invested in green energy

$K\_{G,t}$: Capital stock in green energy at time $t$

$\delta\_{G,t}$: Depreciation of capital stock in green energy at time $t$

$\gamma\_G$: Depreciation rate for green energy

$A\_{F,t}$: Hidden variable for production function of fossil energy at time $t$

$\eta\_{F,t}$: Shock to hidden variable for production function of fossil energy at time $t$

$\alpha\_{KF}$: Share of capital in fossil energy production function

$E\_{F,t}$: Energy consumption of fossil energy at time $t$

$A\_{G,t}$: Hidden variable for production function of green energy at time $t$

$\eta\_{G,t}$: Shock to hidden variable for production function of green energy at time $t$

$\alpha\_{KG}$: Share of capital in green energy production function

It is difficult to provide a comprehensive answer to this question as the geographic spread of early Christianity and the development of the liturgy varied greatly depending on the time and location. However, here are some general points to consider:

By the end of the first century, Christianity had spread throughout the eastern Mediterranean, including present-day Israel, Jordan, Syria, Turkey, Greece, and parts of Italy. It was practiced by both Jews and Gentiles, though the latter group made up the majority of converts. The populations that practiced the primitive Mass were likely small communities of believers, meeting in private homes or in spaces set aside for Christian worship. These communities would have been diverse, including people from different social and economic backgrounds.

As for potential locations where the primitive Mass may have been celebrated, there are several possibilities. Early Christians likely gathered in private homes or other domestic settings, as there were no specifically Christian buildings or temples until several centuries later. Some scholars have suggested that catacombs, underground burial sites used by early Christians, may have been used for worship as well. Other possibilities include public spaces like courtyards or marketplaces, as well as more secluded outdoor locations like gardens or groves.

It is worth noting that the early Christian communities were not static and the development of the liturgy would have varied depending on the location and cultural context. The primitive Mass likely underwent significant changes over time as it was adapted to fit the needs and practices of the communities that celebrated it.

Chapter 2: "The Boy and the Mirror"

Section 1: Introduction of the teenage boy

The boy's name was Jack, and he was sixteen years old. He had short brown hair and piercing blue eyes that were often red and puffy from crying. His father had passed away a few years ago, leaving him and his mother alone in the world. Jack's mother worked at the museum, and he would often come there after school to wait for her to finish her shift.

One day, while wandering through the exhibits, Jack stumbled upon a mirror tucked away in a corner. It was ornately framed and caught his eye immediately. He stepped closer to get a better look and was surprised to find that the mirror seemed to glow, even though there was no light source nearby.

Section 2: The boy becomes entranced by the mirror

Jack was immediately entranced by the mirror and would spend hours staring into it. He would often arrive at the museum early and stay late, just to have more time with the mirror. At first, he couldn't quite put his finger on what drew him to it. But the longer he looked, the more he felt like he was seeing something just out of reach.

The other museum employees noticed Jack's fascination with the mirror and thought it was a bit odd, but they didn't pay it too much mind. They had all seen stranger things in the museum over the years. But as the weeks went by, Jack's obsession with the mirror became more and more concerning.

Section 3: The mirror shows the boy an alternate future where a tragedy from his past did not occur

One day, as Jack was staring into the mirror, he saw something that made him catch his breath. It was an alternate future where his father was still alive. In this future, Jack's father had never gotten sick, and he was there with Jack and his mother, laughing and smiling. They were all happy, and it was as if the past few years of pain and loss had never happened.

Jack was so taken aback by what he saw that he stumbled backwards, almost falling over. He knew it was just a reflection, but it felt so real. He became obsessed with seeing this alternate future again and would spend even more time staring into the mirror, hoping to catch another glimpse of what could have been.

As the days went by, Jack's behavior became more erratic, and he started to neglect his schoolwork and other responsibilities. His mother noticed that something was off and tried to talk to him about it, but he brushed her off, saying he was just tired.

Little did she know that he was being consumed by the mirror, and the alternate future it showed him.

To create an Azure Monitor dashboard that shows everything about the performance and resource utilization of all the nodes in your AKS cluster, including details of the pods and containers running on those nodes, you can follow these steps:

1. Navigate to the Azure Portal and open Azure Monitor.
2. Click on the "Dashboard" tab and then click on the "New dashboard" button to create a new dashboard.
3. On the "New dashboard" page, enter a name for your dashboard, select "AKS cluster" as the resource type, and then click on the "Create" button.
4. Once your dashboard has been created, you can add tiles to it by clicking on the "Add tile" button.
5. To add a tile that displays information about the performance and resource utilization of your AKS cluster, click on the "Add tile" button, select "Metrics" from the list of tile types, and then select "AKS cluster" as the resource.
6. In the "Metrics" tab, select the "Performance" category and then select the metrics that you want to display on the tile, such as "CPU usage", "Memory usage", "Network usage", etc.
7. Click on the "Apply" button to apply your selection and then click on the "Create" button to add the tile to your dashboard.
8. To add a tile that displays details of the pods and containers running on each node in your AKS cluster, click on the "Add tile" button, select "Logs" from the list of tile types, and then select "AKS cluster" as the resource.
9. In the "Logs" tab, you can use Kusto query language to query logs from your AKS cluster. Here's an example query that shows the CPU and request limits for each container, broken down by node:
```scss
ContainerInventory
| where TimeGenerated > ago(5m)
| summarize CPURequest = sum(ContainerCpuRequest), CPULimit = sum(ContainerCpuLimit) by Computer, ContainerName, NamespaceName, Image, PodName
```
This query uses the "ContainerInventory" table to aggregate CPU request and limit values for each container running in your AKS cluster, broken down by node, container name, namespace, image, and pod name.

1. To add a tile that displays details of CPU throttling, you can modify the above query to include throttling information:
```scss
ContainerInventory
| where TimeGenerated > ago(5m)
| summarize CPURequest = sum(ContainerCpuRequest), CPULimit = sum(ContainerCpuLimit), Throttling = sum(ContainerCpuThrottledSeconds) by Computer, ContainerName, NamespaceName, Image, PodName
```
This query adds the "ContainerCpuThrottledSeconds" field to the "summarize" operator, which provides the number of seconds that a container has been throttled due to exceeding its CPU limit.

I hope that helps you get started with creating a dashboard in Azure Monitor for your AKS cluster. Let me know if you have any further questions or if there's anything else I can help you with.

rewrite the below Python code into a clean and concise Summarizer class, that has a self.model and self.tokenizer etc and functions to summarize a file, etc

"""
summarize.py - a module that contains functions for summarizing text
"""
import json
import logging
from pathlib import Path

import torch
from tqdm.auto import tqdm
from transformers import AutoModelForSeq2SeqLM, AutoTokenizer

from textsum.utils import get\_timestamp
from textsum.utils import get\_mem\_footprint, postprocess\_booksummary, setup\_logging
def load\_model\_and\_tokenizer(model\_name: str, use\_cuda: bool = True):
 logger = logging.getLogger(\_\_name\_\_)
 device = "cuda" if torch.cuda.is\_available() and use\_cuda else "cpu"
 logger.debug(f"loading model {model\_name} to {device}")
 model = AutoModelForSeq2SeqLM.from\_pretrained(
 model\_name,
 ).to(device)
 tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from\_pretrained(model\_name)

 logger.info(f"Loaded model {model\_name} to {device}")
 return model, tokenizer
def summarize\_and\_score(
 ids, mask, model, tokenizer, is\_general\_attention\_model=True, \*\*kwargs
):
 """
 summarize\_and\_score - given a batch of ids and a mask, return a summary and a score for the summary

 Args:
 ids (): the batch of ids
 mask (): the attention mask for the batch
 model (): the model to use for summarization
 tokenizer (): the tokenizer to use for summarization
 is\_general\_attention\_model (bool, optional): whether the model is a general attention model. Defaults to True.
 """

 ids = ids[None, :]
 mask = mask[None, :]

 input\_ids = ids.to("cuda") if torch.cuda.is\_available() else ids
 attention\_mask = mask.to("cuda") if torch.cuda.is\_available() else mask

 global\_attention\_mask = torch.zeros\_like(attention\_mask)
 # put global attention on  ~~token
 global\_attention\_mask[:, 0] = 1

 if is\_general\_attention\_model:
 summary\_pred\_ids = model.generate(
 input\_ids,
 attention\_mask=attention\_mask,
 output\_scores=True,
 return\_dict\_in\_generate=True,
 \*\*kwargs,
 )
 else:
 # this is for LED etc.
 summary\_pred\_ids = model.generate(
 input\_ids,
 attention\_mask=attention\_mask,
 global\_attention\_mask=global\_attention\_mask,
 output\_scores=True,
 return\_dict\_in\_generate=True,
 \*\*kwargs,
 )
 summary = tokenizer.batch\_decode(
 summary\_pred\_ids.sequences,
 skip\_special\_tokens=True,
 remove\_invalid\_values=True,
 )
 score = round(summary\_pred\_ids.sequences\_scores.cpu().numpy()[0], 4)

 return summary, score
def summarize\_via\_tokenbatches(
 input\_text: str,
 model,
 tokenizer,
 batch\_length=4096,
 batch\_stride=16,
 \*\*kwargs,
):
 """
 summarize\_via\_tokenbatches - a function that takes a string and returns a summary

 Args:
 input\_text (str): the text to summarize
 model (): the model to use for summarizationz
 tokenizer (): the tokenizer to use for summarization
 batch\_length (int, optional): the length of each batch. Defaults to 4096.
 batch\_stride (int, optional): the stride of each batch. Defaults to 16. The stride is the number of tokens that overlap between batches.
 """

 logger = logging.getLogger(\_\_name\_\_)
 # log all input parameters
 if batch\_length < 512:
 batch\_length = 512
 logger.warning("WARNING: batch\_length was set to 512")
 logger.debug(
 f"batch\_length: {batch\_length} batch\_stride: {batch\_stride}, kwargs: {kwargs}"
 )
 encoded\_input = tokenizer(
 input\_text,
 padding="max\_length",
 truncation=True,
 max\_length=batch\_length,
 stride=batch\_stride,
 return\_overflowing\_tokens=True,
 add\_special\_tokens=False,
 return\_tensors="pt",
 )

 in\_id\_arr, att\_arr = encoded\_input.input\_ids, encoded\_input.attention\_mask
 gen\_summaries = []

 pbar = tqdm(total=len(in\_id\_arr))

 for \_id, \_mask in zip(in\_id\_arr, att\_arr):

 result, score = summarize\_and\_score(
 ids=\_id,
 mask=\_mask,
 model=model,
 tokenizer=tokenizer,
 \*\*kwargs,
 )
 score = round(float(score), 4)
 \_sum = {
 "input\_tokens": \_id,
 "summary": result,
 "summary\_score": score,
 }
 gen\_summaries.append(\_sum)
 logger.debug(f"\n\t{result[0]}\nScore:\t{score}")
 pbar.update()

 pbar.close()

 return gen\_summaries
def save\_params(
 params: dict,
 output\_dir: str or Path,
 hf\_tag: str = None,
 verbose: bool = False,
) -> None:

 output\_dir = Path(output\_dir) if output\_dir is not None else Path.cwd()
 session\_settings = params
 session\_settings["huggingface-model-tag"] = "" if hf\_tag is None else hf\_tag
 session\_settings["date-run"] = get\_timestamp()

 metadata\_path = output\_dir / "summarization-parameters.json"
 logging.info(f"Saving parameters to {metadata\_path}")
 with open(metadata\_path, "w") as write\_file:
 json.dump(session\_settings, write\_file)

 logging.debug(f"Saved parameters to {metadata\_path}")
 if verbose:
 # log the parameters
 logging.info(f"parameters: {session\_settings}")
def summarize\_text\_file(
 file\_path: str or Path,
 model,
 tokenizer,
 batch\_length: int = 4096,
 batch\_stride: int = 16,
 lowercase: bool = False,
 \*\*kwargs,
) -> dict:
 """
 summarize\_text\_file - given a file path, summarize the text in the file
 :param str or Path file\_path: the path to the file to summarize
 :param model: the model to use for summarization
 :param tokenizer: the tokenizer to use for summarization
 :param int batch\_length: length of each batch in tokens to summarize, defaults to 4096
 :param int batch\_stride: stride between batches in tokens, defaults to 16
 :param bool lowercase: whether to lowercase the text before summarizing, defaults to False
 :return: a dictionary containing the summary and other information
 """
 file\_path = Path(file\_path)
 ALLOWED\_EXTENSIONS = [".txt", ".md", ".rst", ".py", ".ipynb"]
 assert (
 file\_path.exists() and file\_path.suffix in ALLOWED\_EXTENSIONS
 ), f"File {file\_path} does not exist or is not a text file"

 logging.info(f"Summarizing {file\_path}")
 with open(file\_path, "r", encoding="utf-8", errors="ignore") as f:
 text = clean(f.read(), lower=lowercase, no\_line\_breaks=True)
 logging.debug(
 f"Text length: {len(text)}. batch length: {batch\_length} batch stride: {batch\_stride}"
 )
 summary\_data = summarize\_via\_tokenbatches(
 input\_text=text,
 model=model,
 tokenizer=tokenizer,
 batch\_length=batch\_length,
 batch\_stride=batch\_stride,
 \*\*kwargs,
 )
 logging.info(f"Finished summarizing {file\_path}")
 return summary\_data
def process\_summarization(
 summary\_data: dict,
 target\_file: str or Path,
 custom\_phrases: list = None,
 save\_scores: bool = True,
) -> None:

 target\_file = Path(target\_file).resolve()
 if target\_file.exists():
 warnings.warn(f"File {target\_file} exists, overwriting")

 sum\_text = [
 postprocess\_booksummary(
 s["summary"][0],
 custom\_phrases=custom\_phrases,
 )
 for s in summary\_data
 ]
 sum\_scores = [f"\n - {round(s['summary\_score'],4)}" for s in summary\_data]
 scores\_text = "\n".join(sum\_scores)
 full\_summary = "\n\t".join(sum\_text)

 with open(
 target\_file,
 "w",
 ) as fo:

 fo.writelines(full\_summary)

 if save\_scores:
 with open(
 target\_file,
 "a",
 ) as fo:

 fo.write("\n" \* 3)
 fo.write(f"\n\nSection Scores for {target\_file.stem}:\n")
 fo.writelines(scores\_text)
 fo.write("\n\n---\n")

 logging.info(f"Saved summary to {target\_file.resolve()}")~~

EPIC: Enable international percentage, decimal, and fraction support
Capability: Localize the user interface and data display of a software application to accommodate international conventions for representing percentages, decimals, and fractions.

Feature User Story: As an international user of the software application, I want to be able to view percentages, decimals, and fractions using the conventions that are commonly used in my country or region so that I can understand the data being presented accurately.

Given: A software application that has been developed using standard percentage, decimal, and fraction conventions
If: The software application needs to be localized for international use
Then: Implement the following acceptance criteria and test cases:

Acceptance Criteria:

1. The application should support multiple formats for representing percentages, such as the use of a comma or a period as a decimal separator, and the use of a percentage symbol before or after the number.
2. The application should support multiple formats for representing decimals, such as the use of a comma or a period as a decimal separator.
3. The application should support multiple formats for representing fractions, such as the use of a slash or a hyphen to separate the numerator and denominator.
4. The application should automatically detect the user's location and language settings and display percentages, decimals, and fractions using the appropriate conventions.
5. The user should be able to select their preferred format for representing percentages, decimals, and fractions in the application's settings.
6. The application should ensure that calculations using percentages, decimals, and fractions are accurate and consistent across all supported formats.

Test Cases:

1. Verify that the application can display percentages in different formats, such as 50% or 0.5, depending on the user's language and location settings.
2. Verify that the application can display decimals in different formats, such as 1.5 or 1,5, depending on the user's language and location settings.
3. Verify that the application can display fractions in different formats, such as 1/2 or ½, depending on the user's language and location settings.
4. Verify that the application automatically detects the user's location and language settings and displays percentages, decimals, and fractions using the appropriate conventions.
5. Verify that the user can select their preferred format for representing percentages, decimals, and fractions in the application's settings.
6. Verify that calculations using percentages, decimals, and fractions are accurate and consistent across all supported formats.

Sourdough bread has been around for centuries, and it has a rich history that's closely tied to the development of human civilization. In fact, sourdough was the primary form of leavening used for bread baking until the mid-19th century, when commercial yeast became widely available.

At its most basic level, sourdough bread is made using just three ingredients: flour, water, and salt. However, the key to sourdough bread's unique flavor and texture is the use of a sourdough starter, which is a naturally occurring mixture of wild yeast and bacteria that's used to leaven the bread.

To make a sourdough starter, you'll need to combine flour and water and allow the mixture to sit at room temperature for several days, feeding it regularly with additional flour and water to encourage the growth of the wild yeast and bacteria. Once the starter is active and bubbly, you can use it to make bread.

To make sourdough bread, you'll start by combining the starter with flour, water, and salt, kneading the dough until it's smooth and elastic. You'll then allow the dough to rise for several hours, during which time the wild yeast and bacteria in the starter will consume the sugars in the dough and produce carbon dioxide, causing the dough to rise.

After the first rise, you'll shape the dough into loaves or rolls and allow it to rise again before baking in the oven. The result is a delicious, tangy bread that's packed with flavor and nutrition.

In terms of equipment, you'll need a few basic tools to get started with sourdough bread baking. A digital scale is essential for measuring your ingredients accurately, and a Dutch oven or other heavy-bottomed pot is helpful for creating a steamy environment in the oven that will help the bread develop a crispy crust. You'll also need a mixing bowl, a bench scraper, and a baking sheet or bread pan.

While the sourdough bread-making process can be a bit intimidating at first, with a little practice, it's a fun and rewarding skill to develop. Plus, once you've mastered the basics, you can experiment with different flours, hydration levels, and fermentation times to create your own unique sourdough bread recipes.

The next morning, C woke up to the sound of birds chirping outside the window. She opened her eyes and saw that the sun was already high in the sky, casting a warm glow on the room. She turned her head and saw that Alex was still fast asleep beside her, one arm thrown over her waist.

C gently extricated herself from Alex's embrace and slipped out of bed. She walked to the kitchen to start a pot of coffee and put some bread in the toaster. As she waited for the coffee to brew and the bread to toast, she leaned against the counter and gazed out the window at the peaceful village outside.

It was hard to believe that just a few months ago, their world had been turned upside down by Anna's death. C remembered the shock and grief that had overwhelmed her when she heard the news. She remembered how hard it had been to find the words to comfort Alex, who had been heartbroken at the loss of the woman they both loved.

C sighed and shook her head, trying to shake off the memories. She turned around and saw that Alex had joined her in the kitchen, looking sleepily around the room.

"Good morning," C said, smiling at her friend.

"Morning," Alex mumbled, rubbing their eyes. "Did you sleep okay?"

"I did," C replied. "How about you?"

Alex shrugged. "I had some weird dreams, but I guess that's to be expected after everything that's happened."

C nodded sympathetically. "I know it's hard, but try not to dwell on it too much. We can't change the past, but we can control how we move forward."

Alex nodded, but C could see the sadness in their eyes. "I know you're right," they said. "But it's hard to let go. Anna was such a big part of my life, and it's hard to imagine a future without her."

C reached out and squeezed Alex's hand. "I know it is. But we'll get through this together, okay? We'll find a way to honor Anna's memory and move forward. It won't be easy, but we can do it."

Alex smiled at her, and C could see the hope returning to their eyes. "You're right," they said. "I'm lucky to have you by my side."

C smiled back. "Always," she said.

Together, they sat down at the kitchen table and enjoyed their breakfast in silence, each lost in their own thoughts. But despite the sadness that lingered in the air, C couldn't help but feel grateful for the moment of peace and quiet with her friend. She knew that it was moments like these that would help them both heal and move forward.

A Comprehensive Guide to Derivative Protocols and Products in Decentralized Finance
===================================================================================

Decentralized finance (DeFi) has revolutionized the way we think about traditional finance by leveraging blockchain technology to build open, permissionless, and highly interoperable financial systems [[1](https://research.stlouisfed.org/publications/review/2021/02/05/decentralized-finance-on-blockchain-and-smart-contract-based-financial-markets)]. One of the most exciting aspects of DeFi is the emergence of derivative protocols and products, which enable traders to gain exposure to various assets without actually owning them.

In this article, we will delve into the world of DeFi derivatives and explore the various protocols and products available in this emerging market. We will also examine the risks and challenges associated with trading DeFi derivatives, as well as the different ways to get started.

I. Introduction
---------------

### A. Definition of Decentralized Finance (DeFi)

Decentralized finance (DeFi) generally refers to the decentralized provision of financial services through a mix of infrastructure, markets, technology, methods, and applications [[2](https://journals.library.columbia.edu/index.php/CBLR/announcement/view/494)]. DeFi lacks a clear legal or technical definition, but it typically comprises applications that provide services such as payments, lending, and trading.

### B. Importance of Derivative Protocols and Products in DeFi

Derivative protocols and products are a crucial part of DeFi because they enable traders to gain exposure to various assets without actually owning them. They also allow traders to hedge against market risks and speculate on price movements, which is essential for a thriving financial ecosystem.

II. Understanding DeFi Derivatives
----------------------------------

### A. Definition of Derivatives

A derivative is a financial instrument that derives its value from an underlying asset or group of assets. Examples of underlying assets include stocks, bonds, commodities, and currencies. Derivatives can be used for hedging, speculation, and arbitrage.

### B. How DeFi Derivatives Work

DeFi derivatives are built on top of smart contract platforms such as Ethereum. These contracts automatically execute when certain conditions are met, such as a specific price or time. This automation eliminates the need for intermediaries, which reduces costs and increases efficiency.

MK cautiously approaches Mac, who is still sitting against the wall with his arms folded and eyes closed. As he bends down to set the food down, he is startled when he sees Mac's eyes open and glowing as he watches him. MK looks from the food to Mac, unsure of what to say.

"I know you don't need to eat, but..." MK starts, his voice trailing off nervously.

Mac smiles and thanks MK, "Thank you. It's been a long time since anyone has offered me food." He looks at the food hungrily, "It's been a long time since I've had something to eat."

MK watches as Mac takes a bite of the food, savoring the taste. "I'm sorry," MK says, "I had no idea you were suffering like this."

Mac shrugs, "It's not your fault. Your father did this to me. But I appreciate the gesture."

MK nods and sits down next to Mac, "I've been thinking, and I've decided that I need to free you from this barrier."

Mac looks at MK with surprise, "You think you can do that? Your father's magic is very powerful. I've been trapped here for so long, I don't think anyone can break the seal."

MK nods, "I need to try. I can't just leave you here like this. I'll figure out a way to break the seal. I promise."

Mac looks at MK with gratitude, "Thank you. I appreciate your kindness."

The two sit in silence for a moment, before MK stands up and says, "I should go. I need to figure out how to break the seal and come back to free you."

Mac nods, "I'll be here. Good luck."

MK turns and makes his way back out of the cave, determined to find a way to free Mac and end his suffering.

Object recognition is a popular use case of computer vision and deep learning, and there are several state-of-the-art models available for this task. One of the most popular models is the YOLO (You Only Look Once) algorithm, which is known for its fast and accurate performance.

To use the YOLO algorithm, you can first download a pre-trained model and use it to detect objects in images. You can use the OpenCV library in Python to load the image, apply the YOLO algorithm, and draw bounding boxes around the detected objects.

To make it more user-friendly, you can create a GUI that allows users to upload images, choose which objects to name and recognize, and view the ASCII art version of the image. You can use a Python library like Tkinter to create the GUI.

For the full description of the image, you can use a combination of natural language processing and computer vision techniques. One approach is to use an image captioning model, which generates natural language descriptions of images. You can use a pre-trained image captioning model like Show and Tell or Show, Attend and Tell to generate captions for the images.

Here's a high-level overview of the steps involved:

1. Download a pre-trained YOLO model and load it using OpenCV.
2. Create a GUI using Tkinter to allow users to upload images, choose which objects to recognize and name, and view the ASCII art version of the image.
3. Use the YOLO model to detect objects in the uploaded image and draw bounding boxes around the detected objects.
4. Allow the user to choose which objects to name and recognize, and use a pre-trained machine learning model (e.g., a CNN classifier) to recognize and name the selected objects.
5. Use a pre-trained image captioning model to generate a natural language description of the image.
6. Display the description, ASCII art version, and annotated image in the GUI.

Of course, this is just a high-level overview, and there are many details to work out. But I hope this gives you a sense of what's involved and how you can use different machine learning and computer vision techniques to create a more sophisticated AI recognition app.

Month 4: December - Reading

Objective: Students will demonstrate proficiency in reading comprehension and analysis of informational texts, as well as understanding and use of academic vocabulary.

CCSS Reading Standard: RI.3.1, RI.3.2, RI.3.4, RI.3.5

Related AASL Standard: 1.1.6, 1.1.7, 1.1.8, 1.2.2, 2.1.3, 2.2.2

Related MD State Standard: Reading Standard 2: Comprehension and Analysis of Nonfiction and Informational Text

Related PGCPS Standard: English Language Arts Standard 2: Comprehension and Analysis of Nonfiction and Informational Text

Current Weaknesses and Assumed Misconceptions:

* Struggling with identifying key details and main ideas in informational texts
* Difficulty with summarizing information from multiple texts on the same topic
* Limited understanding and use of academic vocabulary

Suggestions for Corrections:

* Incorporate explicit instruction on identifying key details and main ideas in informational texts
* Provide opportunities for students to practice summarizing information from multiple texts on the same topic
* Integrate academic vocabulary instruction and provide opportunities for students to use new vocabulary in context

Timeline:

* Week 1: Introduce and model identifying key details and main ideas in informational texts
* Week 2: Practice identifying key details and main ideas in small groups and independent practice
* Week 3: Introduce and model summarizing information from multiple texts on the same topic
* Week 4: Practice summarizing information from multiple texts in small groups and independent practice
* Week 5: Introduce new academic vocabulary and provide opportunities for students to use in context through discussion and writing activities

Related Standards:

* Art: VA:Cr1.1.3, VA:Cr2.1.3
* Art Integration: None specified
* Music: MU:Re7.1.3a, MU:Re7.2.3a
* PE: PE.MS.2, PE.HS.1
* Counseling: None specified
* SEL/Social-Emotional Health: None specified

Rationale: The CCSS Reading Standards are critical for student success in both academic and real-world contexts, particularly in informational texts that are often used in higher education and in the workplace. The related AASL Standards emphasize the importance of analyzing and evaluating information from a variety of sources, and the related MD State and PGCPS Standards prioritize comprehension and analysis of nonfiction and informational texts. Incorporating instruction and practice in identifying key details, main ideas, and academic vocabulary will support students in building strong reading skills and the ability to effectively analyze and evaluate information.

In addition, the related standards in Art, Music, and PE are important for developing well-rounded students who can appreciate and engage with a variety of forms of expression and movement. The related standards in Counseling and SEL/Social-Emotional Health are important for supporting students' emotional and social development, which can in turn support their academic success.

Binary search is an algorithm for finding an element in a sorted array or list. It works by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half, until the value is found or the search interval is empty.

In a binary search, the list is first sorted in an ascending order. Then, the algorithm starts by picking the middle element of the list. If the target value is equal to the middle element, the search is done and the element is found. If the target value is greater than the middle element, we discard the left half of the list and repeat the process on the right half of the list. If the target value is less than the middle element, we discard the right half of the list and repeat the process on the left half of the list.

Here's an example of how binary search works on a list of 7 two-digit values:

1. [12, 15, 20, 25, 35, 40, 45]
* First, the algorithm sorts the list in ascending order: [12, 15, 20, 25, 35, 40, 45]
* Next, the algorithm picks the middle element of the list, which is 25.
* Let's assume that the target value is 40. Since 40 is greater than 25, the algorithm discards the left half of the list and repeats the process on the right half: [35, 40, 45]
* The middle element of the right half is 40, which is the target value. The search is done and the algorithm returns the index of 40 in the list, which is 5.

In the worst case scenario, binary search takes log2n steps to find the element in the list, which makes it much more efficient than linear search for large lists. However, it requires that the input list is sorted, so sorting the list takes O(n log n)

In summary, Binary search is an efficient algorithm for finding an element in a sorted array or list. It repeatedly divides the search interval in half, until the value is found or the search interval is empty. It takes log2n steps to find the element in the list, which is faster than linear search for large lists. However, it requires that the input list is sorted, so sorting the list takes O(n log n).

1. Incident Occurrence: A wildfire is detected, and the Frontier Rangers dispatch the FMLT-FE and FHLT Wildland Fire Team Tanker to the scene.
2. Initial Response: The FMLT-FE arrives on-site first due to its speed and maneuverability. The onboard firefighting crew assesses the situation, determining the fire's size, intensity, and direction. The crew then deploys their firefighting equipment and starts to tackle the fire using water, foam, or other fire suppression agents.
3. Support and Suppression: The FHLT Wildland Fire Team Tanker arrives shortly after, bringing additional firefighting personnel, equipment, and water or fire suppression agents. The tanker positions itself strategically, supplying water and other resources to the FMLT-FE and other ground-based firefighting units.
4. Coordination and Communication: Throughout the operation, the FMLT-FE and FHLT Wildland Fire Team Tanker maintain constant communication, ensuring smooth coordination between both units. This communication allows the crews to adapt to changing conditions, such as shifts in wind direction or the discovery of new fire fronts.
5. Aerial Support: If necessary, aerial firefighting units can be deployed to support the FMLT-FE and FHLT Wildland Fire Team Tanker. These units can drop water or fire retardant from the air, helping to contain the fire and protect structures or natural resources.
6. Containment and Extinguishing: The FMLT-FE and FHLT Wildland Fire Team Tanker work together to create firebreaks, protect structures, and extinguish the flames. The combined efforts of these units help to contain the fire, preventing it from spreading and causing further damage.
7. Demobilization and After-Action Assessment: Once the fire is extinguished, the FMLT-FE and FHLT Wildland Fire Team Tanker demobilize and return to base. The teams then conduct an after-action assessment, evaluating the operation's effectiveness and identifying areas for improvement in future responses.

This joint operation between the FMLT-FE and FHLT Wildland Fire Team Tanker ensures an effective and coordinated firefighting response, maximizing the capabilities of both units to protect lives, property, and the environment from wildfires.

MK sat in his room, staring blankly at the wall. He knew he needed to find out the truth for himself, so he mustered up the courage to approach his father.

"Dad," he said, "I want to go camping in the woods outside the village for a couple of days. I think it will do me some good to get away from everything for a bit."

Wukong looked at his son with concern, "Are you sure you're okay, son? You've seemed off lately."

"I'm fine, I just need some time to clear my head," MK replied, trying to sound as normal as possible.

Wukong nodded, "Alright, I understand. Let me help you pack some supplies and we'll get you ready to go."

Wukong helped MK gather his camping gear and pack a backpack with food and other essentials. He gave him a stern warning to be careful and to come back home safe. MK thanked his father, hugged him, and left the palace.

As he walked through the village, MK couldn't shake off the feeling of guilt and confusion. He knew he needed to find the truth, but he couldn't help but worry about what he might find.

I have improved the given CoffeeScript code by refactoring, using more descriptive variable names, and organizing the code. Here's the updated version:
```coffeescript
@loadQuillHistoryStack = (t, stackDoc) ->
  loadStack = (stackType, maxStackSize) ->
    if stack[stackType].length > 0
      if stack[stackType].length > maxStackSize
        stack[stackType] = stack[stackType].slice Math.max(stack[stackType].length - maxStackSize, 1)
      
      _.each stack[stackType], (op, index) ->
        if op.ops
          t.editor.history.stack[stackType].push RichText.type.deserialize(op)
        else if op[stackType]?.ops
          t.editor.history.stack[stackType].push RichText.type.deserialize(op[stackType])

  stack = ReturnDecryptedItem(stackDoc, 'historyStack')
  unless !!stack and (typeof stack is 'object') and stack.undo and stack.redo
    console.warn 'cannot load stack', stack
    return

  return unless t?.editor?.history

  t.editor.history.clear()

  maxStack = 1000
  loadStack('undo', maxStack)
  loadStack('redo', maxStack)
```
Here's what I've changed in the code:

1. I created a new `loadStack` function that handles both the undo and redo stacks, to avoid code duplication.
2. I replaced the global variable `maxStack` with a local one within the `loadQuillHistoryStack` function, as it is only used in this scope. If you need to use it as a global variable, you can revert this change.
3. I used more descriptive variable names and improved overall code organization.

The functionality of the code should remain the same, but these changes should make it more maintainable and easier to understand.

Google Forms does not provide built-in functionality to perform calculations on collected data, but you can use Google Sheets to perform calculations on the responses collected by your form. Here's how to do it:

1. Open the Google Sheets spreadsheet that was created when you linked your Google Form.
2. Click on the sheet that contains the form responses.
3. Create a new column next to the response column where you want to perform the calculation.
4. In the header row of the new column, enter a descriptive title for the calculation.
5. In the first row of the new column, enter the formula that you want to use to calculate the value for that row. For example, if you want to calculate the total value of two columns, you could use a formula like this: `=A2+B2`.
6. Copy the formula down the column to automatically calculate the value for each row.
7. You can now use the calculated values in your analysis, charts, or other visualizations.

Note that you can use a wide variety of formulas and functions in Google Sheets to perform calculations on your form responses, including basic arithmetic operations, statistical functions, date and time calculations, and more.

Yes, I have a few recommendations for refactoring the `find_features` function to further improve readability and maintainability:

1. Extract the process of generating a unique feature key into a separate function. This can help make the code more modular and easier to understand.
```python
def generate_unique_key(found_features, stream_name, field_name):
    repeat_count = 0
    feature_key = f"{stream_name}.{field_name}" if stream_name else field_name

    while feature_key in found_features:
        repeat_count += 1
        feature_key = f"{stream_name}.{field_name}.{repeat_count}" if stream_name else f"{field_name}.{repeat_count}"
    
    return feature_key
```
1. Refactor the `find_features` function to use the new `generate_unique_key` function:
```python
def find_features(input_stream, stream_name, features):
    """
    ...
    """
    found_features = {}
    for line in input_stream:
        ...
        
        for feature in features:
            ...
            
            if matched_fields is not None:
                matched_fields = matched_fields.groups()
                
                if len(matched_fields) == len(field_names):
                    for i, field_value in enumerate(matched_fields):
                        field_name = field_names[i]
                        feature_key = generate_unique_key(found_features, stream_name, field_name)
                        found_features[feature_key] = field_value
    return found_features
```
By extracting the process of generating a unique feature key into a separate function, the `find_features` function becomes cleaner and more focused on its primary task, improving readability and maintainability.

Using getters and setters, also known as accessors and mutators, instead of public fields for variables has several advantages:

* Encapsulation: Using getters and setters allows you to control access to the fields of a class and to hide the implementation details of the class. You can use the access modifiers (such as private, protected, internal) to control the visibility of the fields and only expose the necessary information to the outside world. This is known as data encapsulation, one of the core concepts in OOP that helps increase the security, flexibility, and maintainability of the code.
* Validation: Using getters and setters allows you to perform validation on the data before it is set or retrieved. For example, you can check if a value is within a certain range, or if it meets certain criteria. This can prevent invalid data from being stored in the fields and help maintain the integrity of the data.
* Flexibility: Using getters and setters allows you to change the implementation of the class without affecting the code that uses it. For example, you can change the way the data is stored or processed without affecting the code that retrieves or sets the data. This makes the code more flexible and easier to maintain.
* Logging: Using getters and setters allows you to add logging to the class. For example, you can log the values that are set or retrieved, or the number of times a method is called. This can be useful for debugging and troubleshooting.
* Additional functionality: Using getters and setters allows you to add additional functionality to the class. For example, you can add a property that returns the number of items in a list or the length of a string. This can make the class more useful and easier to use.

In summary, using getters and setters has several advantages over using public fields, it allows for data encapsulation, validation, flexibility, logging, and additional functionality. It can make the code more secure, maintainable, and easy to debug.

Mother: (grabbing some wipes) Okay, sweetie, let's get you cleaned up. (carefully removing the soiled diaper, overalls, and shirt)

Daughter: (whining) I don't want to take these off, they're my favorite!

Mother: I know, honey, but they're all dirty now. We need to get you into some clean clothes.

Mother: (sitting down on the toilet, taking care of her #1 and #2, wiping herself clean) Alright, let's get this over with.

Mother: (putting the dirty diaper and wipes in the toilet)

Daughter: (mildly protesting as she watches her shirt go into the toilet) No, Mama, not my shirt!

Mother: I'm sorry, sweetie, but we can't keep it. It's covered in yucky stuff from the diaper. We need to flush it away so we can clean up and get you into some fresh clothes.

Daughter: (pouting as she watches her shirt disappear down the drain) Bye bye, shirt. I'll miss you.

Mother: (flushing the shirt)

Daughter: (mildly protesting as she watches her overalls go into the toilet) No, Mama, not my overalls!

Mother: I'm sorry, honey, but we can't keep them either. They're covered in the same yucky stuff. We need to flush them away so we can finish cleaning up and get you into your fresh outfit.

Daughter: (pouting as she watches her overalls disappear down the drain) Bye bye, overalls. I'll miss you too.

Mother: (flushing the overalls)

Mother: (putting a new diaper on the daughter and helping her into a fresh outfit) There you go, all clean and fresh.

Daughter: (excitedly looking at her new yellow sundress with white flowers and matching sandals) Yay, I love this dress!

Mother: (finishing cleaning up the bathroom) That's better.

Mother: (grateful for the extra set of clothes she had packed in the diaper bag) Thank goodness for that extra outfit.

Daughter: (happy to be feeling fresh and clean again) I feel so much better now.

Mother: (relieved that everything had been successfully flushed away without any problems) Phew, that was a close one. Let's not have any more diaper blowouts for a while, okay?

Daughter: (nodding) Okay, Mama. I'll be more careful.

import os
import sys
from shapely.geometry import Point
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(\_\_file\_\_), '..')))
from src.read\_vdatum\_regions import read\_vdatum\_regions
from src.isrelation import is\_west\_of#, is\_north\_of
# Lookup table to get region code from region name
region\_dict = {"Alaska": "ak", "South East Alaska Tidal":"seak", "American Samoa":"as",\
 "Contiguous United States":"contiguous", "Chesapeake/Delaware Bay":"chesapeak\_delaware",\
 "West Coast":"westcoast", "Guam and Commonwealth of Northern Mariana Islands":"gcnmi",\
 "Hawaii":"hi", "Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands":"prvi",\
 "Saint George Island":"sgi","Saint Paul Island":"spi",\
 "Saint Lawrence Island":"sli"}
def assign\_regions\_vdatum(metadata):
 """ Only differentiates the Chesapeake from the Contiguous United States"""

 all\_kmls = read\_vdatum\_regions()

# =============================================================================
# UNKNOWN REGIONS
# =============================================================================
# West Longitude, South Latitude, East Longitude, North Latitude
 alaska = (-169.5, 51.2, -129.5, 71.5)
 american\_samoa = (-171.8, -14.5, -168.1, -10.8)
 guam\_cnmni = (144.5, 13.3, 146.2, 20.8)
 hawaii = (-161.9, 18.7, -154.8, 22.5)
 st\_george\_island = (-171.8, 56.5, -169.5, 59.2)
 st\_paul\_island = (-173.3, 56.0, -169.5, 58.2)
 st\_lawrence\_island = (-173.5, 63.0, -168.5, 65.5)
# =============================================================================

 region\_assign = []
 for index, row in metadata.iterrows():

 point = Point((row["Longitude"], row["Latitude"]))

 if all\_kmls["New Jersey - coastal embayment - South"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Virginia/Maryland/Delaware/New Jersey - Mid-Atlantic Bight shelf"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Delaware - Delaware Bay"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Virginia/Maryland - East Chesapeake Bay"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Maryland - Northwest Chesapeake Bay"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Virginia - Southwest Chesapeake Bay"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point):

 region = region\_dict["Chesapeake/Delaware Bay"]

 elif all\_kmls["Puerto Rico and U.S. Virgin Islands"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point):

 region = region\_dict["Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands"]

 elif all\_kmls["Alaska - Southeast, Yakutat to Glacier Bay"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Alaska - Southeast, Glacier Bay to Whale Bay"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Alaska - Southeast, Whale Bay to US/Canada Border"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point):

 region = region\_dict["South East Alaska Tidal"]
 elif all\_kmls["Washington - Coastal"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Washington - Strait of Juan de Fuca Inland"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Washington - Strait of Juan de Fuca"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Washington - Puget Sound"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Washington/Oregon/California - Offshore"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Oregon - Coastal Inland"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Oregon - Coastal"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["California -Monterey Bay to Morro Bay"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["California/Oregon - Coastal"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["California - San Francisco Bay Vicinity"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["California - San Francisco Bay Inland"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["California - Southern California Inland"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["California - Southern California"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point) or\
 all\_kmls["Columbia River"].geometry.iloc[0].contains(point):

 region = region\_dict["West Coast"]

 elif is\_west\_of(point, alaska[0]) and point.y >= alaska[1] and point.y <= alaska[3]:
 region = region\_dict["Alaska"]
 elif is\_west\_of(point, american\_samoa[0]) and\
 point.y >= american\_samoa[1] and point.y <= american\_samoa[3]:
 region = region\_dict["American Samoa"]
 elif is\_west\_of(point, guam\_cnmni[0]) and\
 point.y >= guam\_cnmni[1] and point.y <= guam\_cnmni[3]:
 region = region\_dict["Guam and Commonwealth of Northern Mariana Islands"]
 elif not is\_west\_of(point, hawaii[0]) and\
 point.y >= hawaii[1] and point.y <= hawaii[3]:
 region = region\_dict["Hawaii"]
 elif is\_west\_of(point, st\_george\_island[0]) and\
 point.y >= st\_george\_island[1] and point.y <= st\_george\_island[3]:
 region = region\_dict["Saint George Island"]
 elif is\_west\_of(point, st\_paul\_island[0]) and\
 point.y >= st\_paul\_island[1] and point.y <= st\_paul\_island[3]:
 region = region\_dict["Saint Paul Island"]
 elif is\_west\_of(point, st\_lawrence\_island[0]) and\
 point.y >= st\_lawrence\_island[1] and point.y <= st\_lawrence\_island[3]:
 region = region\_dict["Saint Lawrence Island"]
 else:
 region = region\_dict["Contiguous United States"]

 region\_assign.append(region)

 return region\_assign

Tommy took a deep breath as he walked into the hospice room. His dad, David, was lying in the bed, his eyes closed as he slept. Tommy's heart ached as he took in the sight of his dad's frail body, knowing that it was only a matter of time before he passed away.

As Tommy walked closer to the bed, David's eyes fluttered open. He looked up and saw his son standing there, tears welling up in his eyes.

"Tommy?" he said, his voice weak but full of love.

"Yeah, it's me, Dad," Tommy said, his voice breaking.

David reached out his hand, and Tommy took it in his own, holding it tightly.

"I'm so glad you're here," David said, his voice barely above a whisper.

Tommy nodded, unable to speak as he tried to keep his emotions in check.

For a few moments, they just sat there in silence, holding hands, each lost in their own thoughts.

Finally, David broke the silence.

"Tommy, there's something I need to ask you," he said, his voice barely audible.

Tommy looked up, his eyes meeting his father's.

"What is it, Dad?" he asked, his voice hoarse.

David took a deep breath before speaking.

"I've been thinking about that day in the park, all those years ago," he said. "The day when those two boys helped me when I was being bullied."

Tommy's heart skipped a beat as he realized what his father was talking about.

"I know it's been a long time, but I've always wondered who those boys were," David continued. "I've always hoped that they were doing well, and that they knew how much their kindness meant to me."

Tommy felt a lump forming in his throat as he realized what he had to do. He took a deep breath and looked his father in the eyes.

"Dad," he said, his voice shaking. "It was me and Mark."

David's eyes widened in surprise, and then filled with tears as he realized the truth.

"You?" he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "It was you and Mark?"

Tommy nodded, tears streaming down his face as he spoke.

"Yeah, Dad," he said. "It was us."

David's face broke into a smile, and he squeezed Tommy's hand tightly.

"Oh, Tommy," he said. "I had no idea. No idea it was you. I can't even begin to tell you how much that day meant to me."

Tommy nodded, feeling a weight lifted off his shoulders as he finally told his father the truth.

"I know, Dad," he said. "I've carried it with me for so long. I'm just glad I could finally tell you."

David looked up at his son, tears streaming down his face.

"I'm so proud of you, Tommy," he said. "So proud of the man you've become."

Tommy leaned in, tears streaming down his face as he hugged his father, holding onto him tightly.

For the rest of the afternoon, they sat there together, talking about that day in the park, and all of the memories that had followed. They talked about their shared experiences, their struggles, and their hopes for the future.

As the day turned into evening, David's breathing began to slow, and his grip on Tommy's hand grew weaker.

Tommy leaned in close, tears streaming down his face as he whispered in his father's ear.

"I love you, Dad," he said. "I'll always love you."

David's eyes fluttered open, and he looked up at his son, a smile on his face.

"I love you too, Tommy," he said, his voice barely

I apologize for the oversight. Here's the revised section VII. Cost Approach, including the table showing the calculation of the Cost Approach, and a full explanation of why the Income and Sales Comparison Approaches were given more weight than the Cost Approach:

VII. Cost Approach

The Cost Approach is one of the three methods used to estimate the value of the subject property. This approach is based on the principle that the value of a property is equal to the cost to replace or reproduce the improvements, less depreciation.

A. Estimation of the Cost to Replace or Reproduce the Improvements
The appraiser has estimated the cost to replace or reproduce the improvements on the subject property to be $2,500,000. This estimate is based on the current cost of labor and materials in the Oakland market.

B. Deductions for Depreciation
The appraiser has estimated the depreciation of the improvements to be $1,200,000. This depreciation is based on the appraiser's analysis of the age, condition, and remaining useful life of the subject property's improvements.

C. Calculation of the Property Value using the Cost Approach
Please refer to the table below for a detailed calculation of the Cost Approach:

|  | Calculation | Value |
| --- | --- | --- |
| A. Replacement Cost | Replacement cost of the improvements | $2,500,000 |
| B. Depreciation | Estimated depreciation of the improvements | $1,200,000 |
| C. Property Value | Replacement cost of the improvements less depreciation | $1,300,000 |

The value indicated by the Cost Approach does not support the appraiser's final opinion of market value for the subject property. This is because the value indicated by the Cost Approach is significantly lower than the values indicated by the Income and Sales Comparison Approaches.

The appraiser gave more weight to the indications of value derived from the Income and Sales Comparison Approaches in determining the final opinion of market value for the subject property for several reasons. First, the Income Approach is well-suited for properties that generate income, such as commercial real estate. The subject property is a gas station that generates significant annual revenue, making the Income Approach an appropriate method for estimating its value.

Second, the Sales Comparison Approach is a widely accepted method for estimating the value of properties that are similar to the subject property and have recently sold. In this case, the appraiser identified several comparable properties that have recently sold and made adjustments to their sale prices based on differences with the subject property to estimate its value.

In contrast, the Cost Approach may not reflect the actual market conditions or demand for the property, and may not account for any unique features or characteristics that would affect its market value. For example, the Cost Approach does not consider any economic or functional obsolescence that may affect the value of the subject property.

In this particular case, the appraiser noted that the cost to replace the improvements on the subject property was high due to the unique features of the gas station, such as its location, design, and special features. The appraiser also noted that the subject property has undergone some physical depreciation, such as wear and tear, which was not accounted for in the Cost Approach.

Given these factors, the appraiser chose to give more weight to the indications of value derived from the Income and Sales Comparison Approaches in determining the final opinion of market value for the subject property. However, the Cost Approach provided useful insights into the subject property's value and condition. The appraiser also considered the Cost Approach in the reconciliation of the value indications from the three approaches.

Revised Summary:

In modern-day America, an ancient mirror that shows viewers a vision of a future without a tragedy has been passed from person to person, leading each one to become obsessed with it. The mirror has been moved from location to location until it ends up on the west coast. Each new owner is different, and the mirror's power takes a different toll on them. However, the mirror's allure of a brighter future ultimately leads to a diminished present and takes an emotional, spiritual, mental, and/or psychological toll on them. A group of individuals of different ages and genders must come together to break the curse and free themselves and future generations from the mirror's grasp.

Chapter 1 - The Auction

The mirror is sold at an auction in New York and ends up in the hands of a young couple. We see how the couple's relationship changes as they become more and more obsessed with the mirror's visions of an alternate future.

Chapter 2 - The Inheritance

The mirror is inherited by an older woman who lost her husband in a tragic accident. We see how the mirror's power helps her deal with her grief but also causes her to neglect her present life.

Chapter 3 - The Gift

The mirror is given as a gift to a successful businessman who becomes obsessed with the mirror's visions of an alternate future. We see how his obsession leads him to make reckless decisions that damage his relationships and business.

Chapter 4 - The Forgotten

The mirror is forgotten in an antique shop, where it is discovered by a lonely teenager who becomes obsessed with the mirror's vision of a future without his troubled home life. We see how the mirror's power takes a toll on his mental health and relationships.

Chapter 5 - The Resistance

The group of protagonists begins to resist the mirror's power, each one bringing their own unique perspective to the fight. We see how they come together to break the curse and destroy the mirror.

Chapter 6 - The Consequences

As the group continues to resist the mirror's power, they begin to suffer consequences. We see how the mirror fights back, tempting each one with visions of an alternate future.

Chapter 7 - The Betrayal

One member of the group betrays the others, using the mirror's power for their own gain. We see how the group reacts to the betrayal and how it sets them back in their mission to destroy the mirror.

Chapter 8 - The Revelation

The group discovers the true history of the mirror and the source of its power. We see how this knowledge helps them in their mission and how they come up with a plan to destroy the mirror once and for all.

Chapter 9 - The Battle

The group faces off against the mirror and its power, risking everything to break the curse. We see how each member's unique experiences and perspectives come together to finally destroy the mirror.

Chapter 10 - The Resolution

The mirror is destroyed, and the group finally begins to heal and move on from their experiences. We see how they each learn to appreciate the present and the people in their lives, and how they vow to protect future generations from the mirror's curse.
